text:
‘No, he hasn’t given Dounia any gifts yet.’

‘Oh! And do you remember, mother, I was in love and wanted to get married?’ he suddenly said, looking at his mother, who was surprised by the sudden change of topic and how he talked about it.

‘Oh, yes, my dear.’

Pulcheria Alexandrovna exchanged looks with Dounia and Razumihin.

‘Hmm, yes. What can I say? I don’t remember much. She was a very sick girl,’ he continued, becoming dreamy and looking down again. ‘She was quite weak. She liked to give money to the poor and always dreamed of being a nun. Once, she cried when she talked to me about it. Yes, yes, I remember. I remember very well. She was not pretty. I really don’t know why I liked her then—I think it was because she was always sick. If she had been lame or hunchbacked, I think I would have liked her even more,’ he smiled dreamily. ‘Yes, it was like a spring madness.’

‘No, it wasn’t just spring madness,’ said Dounia, with strong feeling.

He looked intently at his sister, but didn’t hear or understand her words. Then, completely lost in thought, he got up, went to his mother, kissed her, went back to his seat, and sat down.

‘You still love her?’ asked Pulcheria Alexandrovna, moved.

‘Her? Now? Oh, yes... You’re asking about her? No... that’s...’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on a past love for a sickly girl, revealing his complex feelings and memories.
